rdf:Description.NS0:background: Azerbaijan - a nation of Turkic Muslims - has been an independent republic since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. Despite a cease-fire, in place since 1994, Azerbaijan has yet to resolve its conflict with Armenia over the Azerbaijani Nagorno-Karabakh enclave (largely Armenian populated). Azerbaijan has lost almost 20% of its territory and must support some 750,000 refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) as a result of the conflict. Corruption is ubiquitous and the promise of widespread wealth from Azerbaijan's undeveloped petroleum resources remains largely unfulfilled.
rdf:Description.NS0:location: Southwestern Asia, bordering the Caspian Sea, between Iran and Russia
rdf:Description.NS0:terrain: large, flat Kur-Araz Ovaligi (Kura-Araks Lowland) (much of it below sea level) with Great Caucasus Mountains to the north, Qarabag Yaylasi (Karabakh Upland) in west; Baku lies on Abseron Yasaqligi (Apsheron Peninsula) that juts into Caspian Sea
rdf:Description.NS0:naturalHazard: some lowland areas threatened by rising levels of the Caspian Sea
rdf:Description.NS0:environmentalIssue: local scientists consider the Abseron Yasaqligi (including Baku and Sumqayit) and the Caspian Sea to be the ecologically most devastated area in the world because of severe air, water, and soil pollution
soil pollution results from the use of DDT as a pesticide and also from toxic defoliants used in the production of cotton
rdf:Description.NS0:literacyDefinition: age 15 and over can read and write
rdf:Description.NS0:flagDescription: three equal horizontal bands of blue (top), red, and green; a crescent and eight-pointed star in white are centered in red band
rdf:Description.NS0:economyOverview: Azerbaijan's most prominent products are oil, cotton, and natural gas. Azerbaijan's oil production declined through 1997 but has registered an increase every year since. Negotiation of 19 production-sharing arrangements (PSAs) with foreign firms, which have thus far committed $60 billion to oil field development, should generate the funds needed to spur future industrial development. Oil production under the first of these PSAs, with the Azerbaijan International Operating Company, began in November 1997. Azerbaijan shares all the formidable problems of the former Soviet republics in making the transition from a command to a market economy, but its considerable energy resources brighten its long-term prospects. Baku has only recently begun making progress on economic reform, and old economic ties and structures are slowly being replaced. An obstacle to economic progress, including stepped up foreign investment, is the continuing conflict with Armenia over the Nagorno-Karabakh region. Trade with Russia and the other former Soviet republics is declining in importance while trade is building up with Turkey, Iran, UAE, and the nations of Europe. Long-term prospects will depend on world oil prices, the location of new pipelines in the region, and Azerbaijan's ability to manage its oil wealth.
rdf:Description.NS0:telephoneSystemGeneralAssessment: inadequate; requires considerable expansion and modernization; teledensity of 8.6 main lines per 100 persons is very low
rdf:Description.NS0:telephoneSystemDomestic: the majority of telephones are in Baku and other industrial centers - about 700 villages still do not have public telephone service; satellite service connects Baku to a modern switch in its exclave of Naxcivan
rdf:Description.NS0:telephoneSystemInternational: the old Soviet system of cable and microwave is still serviceable; a satellite connection to Turkey enables Baku to reach about 200 additional countries, some of which are directly connected to Baku by satellite providers other than Turkey (1997)
rdf:Description.NS0:internationalDispute: Armenia supports ethnic Armenians in the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan in the longstanding, separatist conflict against the Azerbaijani Government
Caspian Sea boundaries are not yet determined among Azerbaijan, Iran, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Turkmenistan
rdf:Description.NS0:illicitDrugs: limited illicit cultivation of cannabis and opium poppy, mostly for CIS consumption
transshipment point for opiates via Iran, Central Asia, and Russia to Western Europe

rdf:Description.NS0:note: these roads are said to be hard-surfaced, and include, in addition to conventionally paved roads, some that are surfaced with gravel or other coarse aggregate, making them trafficable in all weather
